p: Thirdly, the effect of the invasion of H. axyridis on aphid populations is still poorly documented in Europe. Unverified information points to a decreasing trend, or at least a status-quo, in aphid-related agricultural problems, which would confirm that the arrival of H. axyridis did not alter the natural aphid control function of ladybirds by affecting native ladybird populations. However, it is not excluded that H. axyridis has a direct negative effect on native aphid populations, in particular aphids living on deciduous trees. Although it is difficult, long after the invasion of H. axyridis, to measure this effect accurately, it is possible that old and long-term data from aphid populations can be compared to new surveys carried out using the same protocols.
